博物汇编艺术典医部全录目录 - Preface to the Complete Collection of Medical Works in Ancient and Modern Times

Translation created with model: gpt-4o-mini-2024-07-18

Return to index

Translation

Preface to the Complete Collection of Medical Works in Ancient and Modern Times

Chen Menglei, a native of Minhou in Fujian, passed the imperial examination during the Kangxi era and was later appointed to editorial positions. Due to his straightforward nature and unwavering loyalty, he offended some individuals, which led to false accusations and imprisonment. He endured ten years of legal battles before being released home. He believed that peace had returned, but unexpectedly, he was arrested again at the beginning of the Yongzheng era and ultimately died in prison. During his time outside, he collected all medical literature from a century earlier and compiled the "Complete Collection of Medical Works," the largest medical book in our country. This work is based on the original texts of renowned Qing dynasty physicians, such as Jiang Tingxi, published in the year, and is part of the "Complete Collection of Ancient and Modern Books." The original text comprises approximately ten million characters, making it the largest medical work throughout Chinese history. The book includes annotations of medical classics, diagnostics, theoretical experiences of various diseases, and related literary works, records, and biographies of famous physicians, serving as a resource for general medical practitioners.[1p]

    Slow Pulse Is Not Necessarily a Disease Pulse[23p]
    The meaning of the pulse is not simply about change.
    The pulse is based on the stomach’s qi.
    Diagnosis differs from that of Shuhe.
    Emphasis on both yin and yang.
    Separating yin from yang.
    Yin and yang interdepend, one suppressing the other.
    When yin is absent, yang is also absent.
    The pulse lacking roots has two interpretations.
    Pulse is distinguished by channel and collateral.
    In a year, the pulse representations cannot be observed again.
    The pulse shows overactivity and control.
    Differences exist between the pulse of the old and the young.
    Diagnose based on the evidence rather than the pulse.
    Rely on the pulse over the evidence.
    Though seven diagnoses reveal the nine conditions, those who follow will not perish.
    Chong, Yang, Taixi, and Taichong.
    Dividing the ren and qi, the pulse methods are established.
    Internal cause pulse.
    External cause pulse.
    Neither internal nor external cause pulse.
    Deathly pulse.
    Motion and stillness of the pulse.
    Various pulse indications and contraindications.
    The six essentials of medical principles. — Ming Dynasty, Zhang Sanxi.
    In pulse diagnosis, the intention is paramount.
    Location of the organs.
    Women’s pulse.
    Reflected pulse.[24p]

    Taisu Pulse Treatise by Peng Yongguang of the Ming Dynasty
    Liver Meridian Indicates Joy
    Liver Meridian Indicates Nobility
    If the Liver Meridian Flows Smoothly and Rises and Falls, it Indicates the Nobility and Wealth of Official Positions, Achieving Glory in Middle Age.
    Liver Meridian Clarity and Turbidity

    Defining the Annual Flow of Spring Meridian Patterns
    Spring Month Aligns with Seasonal Trends
    General Discussion on Heart Meridian Patterns
    Heart Meridian Indicates Nobility [31p]
  • Heart pulse reveals wisdom
  • Heart pulse reveals disaster
  • Heart pulse reveals official misfortune and parental suffering
  • Heart pulse reveals loneliness
  • Heart pulse reveals poverty
  • Heart pulse reveals worry and shock
  • Heart pulse reveals women's promiscuity
  • Heart pulse signifies illness and death
  • Spring reveals heart pulse
  • Heart pulse reveals illness and death
  • Summer reveals heart pulse
  • Autumn reveals heart pulse
  • Winter reveals heart pulse
  • Establishing the year, summer pulse follows the pattern
  • Summer month aligns with the season's rhythm
  • Lung pulse reveals nobility
  • Lung pulse reveals dreams
  • Lung pulse reveals paternal nobility
  • Lung pulse reveals misfortune
  • Lung pulse reveals joy, spouses are harmonious
  • Lung pulse signifies low status and fondness for travel
  • Lung pulse signifies punishment and law
  • Lung pulse signifies lack of virtue
  • Lung pulse reveals a high-status wife
  • Lung pulse reveals filial mourning
  • Spring reveals lung pulse
  • Summer reveals lung pulse
  • Autumn reveals lung pulse
  • Winter reveals lung pulse[32p]
    Regulations for Determining Annual Trends in Autumn

The autumn moon follows the season and announces:

  • The kidney pulse indicates joy.
  • The kidney pulse indicates wealth.
  • The kidney pulse indicates longevity.
  • The kidney pulse indicates joy of pregnancy.
  • The kidney pulse indicates official positions and short life.
  • The kidney pulse indicates talent and wisdom.
  • The kidney pulse indicates joy in desires.
  • The kidney pulse indicates blessings and longevity.
  • The kidney pulse indicates disasters and diseases.
  • The kidney pulse indicates excessive lust.
  • The kidney pulse indicates great learning without achievement.
  • The kidney pulse indicates many disasters in old age.
  • The kidney pulse indicates lawsuits and illness.
  • The kidney pulse indicates death and calamities.
  • The kidney pulse, along with the life gate, indicates fortune in servants and carriages, both good and bad.
  • The kidney and life gate together indicate loss of wealth due to official mandates and major disasters.
  • The kidney pulse is not suitable for wives and concubines.
  • The kidney pulse suggests adverse effects on kin and offspring.
  • The kidney pulse indicates illness and the shortening of life.
  • The kidney pulse indicates cultivation for longevity, either long or short.

The kidney pulse in spring,
The kidney pulse in summer,
The kidney pulse in autumn,
The kidney pulse in winter,
Regulations for determining annual trends in winter.[33p]
Winter Month, Seasonal Observations

General Discussion on the Spleen Pulse
The Spleen Pulse shows joy.
The Spleen Pulse indicates achievement, allowing for official titles and wealth.
The Spleen Pulse reveals innate skill but no official position.
The Spleen Pulse denotes a noble wife and longevity.
The Spleen Pulse suggests low status.
The Spleen Pulse indicates disaster and danger.
The Spleen Pulse foresees trouble with earth-related calamities.
The Spleen Pulse suggests a malevolent death.
The Spleen Pulse reflects unrest in the household.
The Spleen Pulse indicates official positions and wealth.
The Spleen Pulse reveals profound principles.
The Spleen Pulse signifies calamity.

General Discussion on the Spleen Pulse
Visible in Spring
Visible in Summer
Visible in Autumn
Visible in Winter

Confucian Teaching on Filial Piety, Yuan Dynasty, Zhang Congzheng
Nine Qi Influence Illness and Mutual Treatment
Internal and External Four Qi
Illnesses Caused by Wind and Wood Congestion
Illnesses Caused by Heat and Fire Congestion
Illnesses Caused by Dampness and Earth Congestion
Illnesses Caused by Dryness and Metal Congestion
Illnesses Caused by Cold and Water Congestion
Initial Qi
Second Qi
Third Qi
Fourth Qi[76p]
Five Elements of Qi
Final Qi
Wind corresponds to wood, the liver is sour, treats with needles.
Heat corresponds to fire, the heart is bitter, induces sweating.
Dampness corresponds to earth, the spleen is sweet, removes needles.
Dryness corresponds to metal, the lungs are spicy, clears with needles.
Cold corresponds to water, the kidneys are salty, bends needles.
Great cold corresponds to the initial Qi of the child above.
Spring equinox corresponds to the second Qi of the rabbit above.
Lesser fullness corresponds to the third Qi of the snake above.
Great heat corresponds to the fourth Qi of the horse above.
Autumn equinox corresponds to the fifth Qi of the rooster above.
Lesser snow corresponds to the final Qi of the pig above.
Wind treatment method.
Heat treatment method.
Dampness treatment method.
Fire treatment method.
Dryness treatment method.
Cold treatment method.
Wind entry is treated solely within.
Heat entry is treated solely without.
Damp entry is treated both within and without.
Fire entry is treated both within and without.
Dry entry is first treated within, then treated without.
Cold entry is first treated without, then treated within.
From the "Ten Treatises of Dongyuan," Yuan Dynasty, by Li Gao.
Southern governance, Northern governance.[77p]

    Hearing loss has six conditions

    Qi deficiency hearing loss should occur after a major illness
    Hearing loss should primarily focus on circulating qi and relieving stagnation

Medical Introduction by Li Zhan from the Ming Dynasty
Division of Eyes: Internal and External
Five Wheels and Eight Borders
White pertains to the Lungs; Black pertains to the Liver
Inner and Outer Canthi pertain to the Heart and Small Intestine
Upper and Lower Eyelids pertain to the Stomach and Spleen
Pupil pertains to Kidney Water
Eight Borders' Locations
Women and Children
Acute Redness, Swelling, Pain, and Itching
Pterygium, Tears, and Blurred Vision belong to the Exterior
Blurred vision and sensitivity to light
Internal Obstructions with Dark Flowers and Obscured Pupils
Myopia indicates Yin Deficiency; Hyperopia indicates Yang Deficiency
Cold Tears and Eye Pain
External Causes: Wind, Heat, Dampness, and Phlegm[101p]
Internal injury to qi and blood
Combined wind-heat and deficiency
Eye diseases are primarily due to fire
Decline of yang should be treated with warmth
Lotions for eye washing should be used with caution

Swelling is like a cup,
Form resembles a shrimp,
Appearance like a fish bladder.[106p]
Hawk-eyed and sharp-eyed,
In the wind, they become venomous.
The spiral shell emerges,
With the tip of the spiral rising.
The divine pearl swells,
As the pearl protrudes from the socket.
Discussing eye itch,
It itches as if bugs are crawling.
Discussing external obstruction,
Yellow films surge upward,
While red membranes droop down.
Creacting fat blockages,
Flowery blockages invade white.
Crab eyes and

Yellow oil obstructions,
In appearance like a suspended gallbladder.
Jade grains divide the channels,
Silver stars are seen alone.

The text appears to be a collection of diagnostic terms and descriptions related to eye conditions, along with various symptoms and phenomena observed in the eyes. Here is the translation:

  Crescent moon encroaches on the eye  
  Jujube flower barrier  
  White haze with yellow center  
  Black flower dimming  
  Volume One Hundred Forty-Three  
  Evidence and Treatment Standards - Ming Dynasty, Wang Kengtang  
  Five winds transform into internal obstacles  
  Pupil is dilated  
  Pupil is tight and small  
  Pupil is tilted  
  Discussing blurred vision  
  Vision is dim and unclear  
  Yellow eye with unclear vision  
  Dryness causes blurred vision  
  Rising and sitting induces distortion  
  Fireflies fill the eyes  
  Sudden blindness  
  Blue blindness  
  Sparrow blindness  
  Genuine eye ointment damage  
  Ointment injures the pearl  
  Divine fluid is about to dry  
  Wheel turns at the gate  
  Both eyes are clear  
  Divine pearl is about to reflect  
  Pupil is turned back  
  Blue and yellow emerge  
  Energy moves in the pearl  
  Inverted eyelashes and clenched hairs  
  Fierce tightness in the eyes  
  Flesh sticky to the wheel  
  Tissue glued together

    Confucian Teachings on Filial Piety (Yuan Dynasty, Zhang Congzheng)[232p]
    On Malaria: Not Caused by Spleen Cold or Spirits

On Curing Malaria

From the "Ten Books of Dongyuan" by Li Gao, Yuan Dynasty:

  • Summer injuries lead to malaria in autumn.
  • Treatment should follow the seasons.
  • Discusses malaria related to the five organs.
  • Discusses malaria related to the six meridians.

From the "Heart Method of Danxi" by Zhu Zhenheng, Yuan Dynasty:

  • Symptoms and treatment of malaria.

From "Extra Discussions on Grit and Reality" by Zhu Zhenheng, Yuan Dynasty:

  • Treatise on malaria.

From "Key Points in Diagnosis and Treatment" by Dai Sigong, Ming Dynasty:

  • Symptoms and treatment of malaria.

From "Miscellaneous Writings of Ming Medicine" by Wang Lun, Ming Dynasty:

  • Symptoms and treatment of malaria.

Volume 289

From "Introduction to Medicine" by Li Zhan, Ming Dynasty:

  • Differentiating Yin and Yang.
  • Distinguishing cold and heat.
  • Clarifying the six meridians.
  • Sensitivity to external influences.
  • Treatment through sweat, vomiting, and purging.
  • Deficiency and exhaustion.
  • Phlegm-related conditions.
  • Food stagnation.
  • Causes of malaria.
  • Concurrent dysentery.
  • Variations of cold damage.
  • Symptoms resembling malaria.
  • Predominance of heat and insignificance of cold.[233p]

To treat chest obstruction, fullness, and throat pain:

Taiyin Meridian Diagnosis and Treatment:

  • Abdominal pain
  • Abdominal distention
  • Cold and heat after sweating

Shaoyin Meridian Diagnosis and Treatment:

  • Vomiting and diarrhea
  • Diarrhea
  • Cough
  • Throat pain and dryness
  • Nosebleeds
  • Agitation

Jueyin Meridian Diagnosis and Treatment:

  • Cold extremities
  • Yin toxicity
  • Vomiting of long worms

Volume 341 of "The Living Book" by Zhu Gong of the Song Dynasty:

  • Bowel movements
  • Urination
  • Similar to malaria
  • Excessive sleep
  • Inability to sleep
  • Exterior and interior syndromes
  • Without exterior and interior syndromes
  • Exterior heat and interior cold, exterior cold and interior heat
  • Discussion of the similarities and differences between febrile diseases and warm diseases
  • When Yang is deficient and Yin is excessive, sweating leads to recovery; purging leads to death. When Yang is excessive and Yin is deficient, sweating leads to death; purging leads to recovery.
  • Discussion on methods of sweating and purging.[283p]

    Observe shape
    Inspect the nose
    Examine the lips, teeth, and gums in detail
    Inspect the ears
    Examine the eyes
    Assess the tongue
    Press on the chest to identify areas of pain
    Inquire about the frequency of urination and bowel movements
    Ask about thirst or lack thereof
    Palpate the pulse using appropriate techniques
    Consider floating, sinking, and the three pulse patterns to determine illness

The yang syndrome resembles the yin,
The yin syndrome resembles the yang.
The taiyang pulse resembles the shaoyin, and the shaoyin syndrome resembles the taiyang.

  • Fetal heat
  • Variation in steaming

Secrets of Infant Care
By Wanquan, Ming Dynasty
Heavenly Fishing and Inner Fishing[370p]
卷四百二十六
婴童百问 明·鲁伯嗣
发搐 (Convulsions)
急惊 (Sudden fright)
慢惊 (Chronic fright)
脾风 (Spleen wind)
急慢脾风下痰轻重 (Severity of phlegm in sudden and chronic spleen wind)
惊癎 (Fright epilepsy)
惊风 (Fright wind)
天钓内钓 (Heavenly and internal fishing)
医学正传 明·虞抟
急慢惊风论 (Discussion on sudden and chronic fright wind)
明医杂着 明·王纶
小儿病多属肝脾二经 (Children's diseases largely pertain to the liver and spleen channels)
急惊 (Sudden fright)
急惊变慢惊 (Sudden fright transforming into chronic fright)
惊搐 (Fright-induced convulsions)
小儿用药不宜峻厉 (Medications for children should not be harsh)
惊后目动咬牙 (Teeth grinding and eye movement after fright)
出痘发搐 (Convulsions following smallpox)
惊搐等证误用药饵 (Misuse of medicines in cases of convulsions and similar symptoms)

Volume 435
Standard for Diagnosis and Treatment – Ming Dynasty, Wang Kengtang
Vomiting and Diarrhea
Treatment for Summer and Autumn
Treatment for Winter and Spring[375p]
Body heat with yellow diarrhea and thirst should be treated with cool agents.
Cold limbs with green diarrhea and no thirst should be treated with warm medicine.
Warm limbs with yellow and white diarrhea resembling thirst indicate a combination of cold and heat diseases.
Retention of food, abdominal pain, and the following prohibitions:
Vomiting;
Cold vomiting;
Hot vomiting;
Poisonous gas vomiting;
Breast injury vomiting;
Diarrhea;
Cold diarrhea;
Hot diarrhea;
Food injury diarrhea;
Shock diarrhea;
Acute diarrhea;
Chronic diarrhea;
Dinner diarrhea.

Here is the translation of the provided Classical Chinese text:

  • Reverse effects manifest
  • Death symptoms
  • Ulceration
  • Difficult symptoms
  • Violate prohibitions
  • Feverishness
  • Persistent sores
  • Tremors
  • Scab falling
  • Residual toxins
  • Many ailments post-pox
  • Post-pox conditioning
  • Women's pox
  • Pregnant women's pox
  • Rashes treatise
  • West River Moon
  • Treating rashes and miscellaneous diseases
  • Volume 462
  • Remarkable effective remedies by Ming Dynasties' Fang Xian
  • Treatise on sores and rashes preface
  • Treatise on sores and rashes
  • Each of the five organs has a symptom
  • Discussing the duration of days
  • If arising from the heart, then pre-embarrassment
  • Appears to emerge but doesn't fully
  • The emergence has reverse and sequential forms
  • Delayed emergence has specific symptoms
  • Discussing changing heat conditions into sore symptoms
  • Causes of convulsions
  • Discussing regulating and benefiting
  • Discussing differences between superficial and internal conditions
  • Various sores, pox, and skin rashes.[395p]
    Fever, when accompanied by rashes, indicates a light condition. Once manifested, it should not be dealt with carelessly or hastily.

The reasons for the emergence of heat toxins are diverse.

Once the symptoms appear, oil-based remedies should be avoided.

There are instances of eruptions, warmth, and detoxification.

Even with heat symptoms, if bowel movements remain normal, one should not purge again. Reckless treatment can lead to adverse outcomes.

When fever appears at intervals, one should be aware of its association with lesions, rashes, vesicles, and pustules, indicating accumulated heat and toxins.

Once manifested, symptoms may still be unbalanced; they have not properly resolved internally.

When fever is present along with pain, it does not subside quickly.

A greenish complexion suggests a counterflow of energy.

A hot body but a slow pulse indicates that, unless there is slight sweating, the exterior remains unresolved.

If symptoms have emerged but are not entirely resolved, they can still linger and may not evolve into blood blisters.

If there are no symptoms, treatment may proceed; if symptoms have manifested, they should not be hastily treated. Once established, one should encourage proper bowel movements.

Fever may vary in intensity.

Heat at the surface should not be neglected, especially if it is strong.

In cases similar to febrile diseases and rashes, one must identify and treat appropriately; if unsure, herbs like Schizonepeta or cilantro wine should be used.

When energy flows smoothly, it indicates a quick resolution.[396p]
Wounds have turned into pus-filled sores, causing restlessness. The body is hot, ears cold at the tips, feet cold, and there is pain like a lump in the abdomen. Care must be taken. The hands and feet are cold, and the abdomen is hard due to sores and rashes. If the rash is not visibly present, one may proceed with laxatives. The stone wall contains treatises and a song on sores and rashes, differentiating between Liu’s theories and Zhang’s use of medication.

In volume 463: miraculous effects and good prescriptions from the Ming Dynasty, by Fang Xian.

Sores and rashes caused by heat are different from various other types of heat. Evaluate their severity. Laxatives differ from those used to spur movement. Distinguish between Dong Ji’s guidance and Qian’s book on healing people, as the prescriptions should differ.

Avoid hunger and exposure to cold winds. Severe heat requires promoting urination; moderate heat requires detoxification. If urine is red and there's abdominal swelling, first promote elimination and then detox; avoid excessive laxatives.

Restlessness and thirst arise. Sleep is restless, with conditions like being bitten by mosquitoes or fleas, the poison strong and color dark. Administer cool medicines cautiously.

If there is blood in the stool and it appears black, there may be unconsciousness. If already released, but the abdomen is swollen.[397p]
At this moment, it is urgent to save;
Stopping too early brings fear,
Which mistakenly leads to treatment.
Rashes may occur with bowel movements, during warmth, or suddenly;
They can manifest as vomiting, diarrhea, or loss of appetite.
Rashes are often superficial and should not be hastily treated.
Hideous marks and dark sores can lead to fever.
Dark conditions may show both reversal and progress.
Delayed occurrences manifest through day and night cries.
Swelling and sores appear.
Bowel movements remain normal.
If hot medicines are taken, it harms the eyes; cold medicines can lead to untimely harm.
Spots may rot.
Catching a chill mixed with rashes invokes heat, causing toxins to remain unresolved.
Medications for infants and children must differ.
What is inherently rare should not be forced out.
If there is no stagnation, do not force outward treatment or purging.
Scabs can arise while still able to eat.
If black and retentive but not yet showing cold symptoms,
Beware of various adverse conditions.
First, know the seasonal signs and the balance of yin and yang within the organs—both strengths and weaknesses.
Engaging in sexual activity irritates the condition, similar to burn of red herb and pig's hoof.
Newborns taking raw Rehmannia juice prevents sores from forming;
Deep sores can poison and cause the stomach to rot, leading to bloody stools.[398p]
Excessive toxins that have not been resolved lead to vomiting and various mixed symptoms. Preemptively taking oil preparations can detoxify.

Rashes with fever, difficulty in defecation, and blood-like urine; or the presence of boils and body ruptures. Misuse of colocynthis will result in internal deficiency and heat unrelieved. Avoid using colocynthis, mercury, or light powder.

Heat toxins invade the liver and affect the eyes.

Coughing and side pain after sores.

In cases of cold-induced fever with urgent heat toxins, it's essential to release the exterior.

Persistent remaining toxins cause thirst and chest fullness.

No scabbing or sores healing.

Differentiate between types of sores and ice sores entering the large intestine.

Tubercular swellings and toxicity.

Winter warmth presents rashes resembling brocade patterns.

Use Baixiang pills for related symptoms.

Post-sore eye problems should avoid topical medications.

In winter, preemptively take San Dou drink.

Preventive measures for eye infections from sores.

Sore toxicity attacks the throat.

Urination and defecation difficulties.

Excessive medicines for infants can lead to complications.

In cases of winter warmth, it’s best to clear toxins first.

Pus not drying.

Medications for eye conditions.

Symptoms of smallpox resemble those of typhus;

The date cannot be used to judge the condition;
Adults and children, the rich and poor differ greatly.

Sichuan herb soup relieves it;

The change to black has both reverse and forward elements;

Clarifications on Phlegm Confusing the Upper Orifices, Leading to Dullness and Silence [421p]
Expressing tranquility and restlessness, with a sorrowful face that can be touched.
The joints are troubled and painful, the waist feels beaten.
The muscles are tense and the veins alert.
The body is overwhelmingly hot.
The limbs are singularly cold.
Sweat pours from the whole body.
Sweat on the head is like steam.
Poison surges, causing swelling.
There are lumps and bumps.
There are pre-sealed and pre-swollen areas.
Red threads encircle the eyes, with hair standing on end.
Pimples appear like dirt, with foul breath that repels others.
The hair begins to clench the teeth.
The hair starts to twist the tongue.
Both cheeks are flushed red, without a single pimple.
Emerging like needles.
Darkness sinks awkwardly.
Purple spots float like duckweed.
There are flea-like marks.
Clusters of unusual pimples resembling beads.
Awful colors and the corresponding treatment.
Four types of poison emerge.
The pimples are good evidence of malice.
White pimples are bold indicators.
Impending flow.
Bubbles surge.[422p]

Chronicles - Miscellaneous Records - Outside Collection
Volume Five Hundred Twenty
Chronicles
Miscellaneous Records
Outside Collection [470p]

Original

古今图书集成医部全录 （清˙陈梦雷等编）前言

　　 陈梦雷，福建闽候人，在康熙年间中了进士，以后被授予编修等职。因为他性情直爽，又忠心耿直，得罪了一些人，所以被诬告而入狱，吃了十年官司，才被释放回家。他自以为太平无事了，谁知到雍正初又被莫名其妙地捉了去，最后死在牢狱中。在他自由在外的时候，搜集了世纪以前的全部医学文献，主编了《医部全录》这部我国最大的医学类书。　　本书系清代名医蒋廷锡等原著，刊行于年，是<古今图书集成>的一部分。原著卷，约千万字，是中国历代以来最大的一部医学类书。全书包括医经注释、诊断、各科疾病的理论经验，以及有关医学的艺文、记事和名医列传等。可供一般医务工作者阅读和参考。古今图书集成医部全录目录[1p]

　　　 卷七十三
　　　　 黄帝素问　三
　　 　　　 四时刺逆从论
　　　　　 五运行大论
　　　　　 至真要大论

　　　　　 方盛衰论
　　　　 灵枢经
　　 　　　 邪气脏腑病形篇

　　　 卷七十五
　　　　 脉经　一
　　　　　 脉形状指下秘诀第一[12p]
　　　　　 平脉早晏法第二
　　　　　 分别三关境界脉候所主第三　　 　　　 辨尺寸阴阳荣卫度数第四　　 　　　 平脉视人大小长短男女逆顺法第五　　 　　　 持脉轻重法第六
　　 　　　 两手六脉所主五脏六腑阴阳逆顺第七　　 　　　 辨脏腑病脉阴阳大法第八　　 　　　 辨脉阴阳大法第九
　　 　　　 平虚实第十
　　 　　　 从横逆顺伏匿脉第十一
　　 　　　 辨灾怪恐怖杂脉第十二
　　 　　　 迟疾短长杂脉法第十三
　　 　　　 平人得病所起脉第十四
　　 　　　 诊病将差难已脉第十五
　　 　　　 平三关阴阳二十四气脉第十六　　 　　　 平人迎神门气口前后脉第十七　　 　　　 平三关病候并治宜第十八　　 　　　 平奇经八脉病第十九

　　 　　　 东垣十书　元·李杲
　　　　　　 脾胃虚实传变论
　　　　　　 脏气法时升降浮沉补泻说　　　　　　 脾胃胜衰论
　　　　　　 肺之脾胃虚
　　　　　　 肾之脾胃虚
　　　　　　 饮食劳倦所伤始为热中论　　　　　　 脾胃虚弱随时为病随病制方　　 　　　　 脾胃虚不可妄用吐药论　　　　　　 脾胃虚则九窍不通论
　　　　　　 脾胃虚脏腑经络皆无所受气而俱病论　　 　　　　 脾脏苦欲补泻药味
　　　　　　 脾数三
　　　　　　 饮食伤脾论
　　　　　　 脾胃损在调饮食适寒温　　　　　　 脾胃将理法

　　 　　　 病因

　　 　　　 兼证用茵陈蒿汤加减例

　　 　　　 虚损论
　　 　　 东垣十书　元·李杲
　　 　　　 脾胃虚弱随时为病随病制方　　 　　　 脾胃虚不可妄用吐药论
　　 　　　 脾胃虚则九窍不通论
　　 　　　 胃虚则脏腑经络皆无所受气而俱病论　　 　　　 胃虚元气不足诸病所生论　　 　　 丹溪心法　元·朱震亨
　　 　　　 劳瘵

　　 　　　 知可解
　　 　　　 证知解不解
　　 　　　 脉知解不解

　　 　　　 当汗而下成协热利

　　 　　　 作渴调补精气第四十七
　　 　　　 将安发热作渴第四十八
　　 　　　 口干作渴不同第四十九
　　 　　　 肾虚发热第五十
　　 　　　 将安当补第五十一
　　 　　　 服药捷径第五十二
　　 　　　 调节饮食当平胃气第五十三　　 　　　 成漏脉例第五十四

　　 　　　 经候不调有三
　　 　　　 先期经行治法
　　 　　　 后期经行治法
　　 　　　 数月经一行治法
　　 　　　 或前或后治法
　　 　　　 过多过少治法
　　 　　　 经闭不行有三

　　 　　　 首尾皆宜汗下

　　 　　　 论疮疹
　　 　　　 五脏各有一证
　　 　　　 论日数
　　 　　　 出于心则先惊搐
　　 　　　 似出不出
　　 　　　 出有逆顺
　　 　　　 出迟有数证
　　 　　　 论诸热失治变为疮疹候
　　 　　　 作搐
　　 　　　 论疏利
　　 　　　 论表出与温里不同
　　 　　　 诸疮痘肤疹[395p]
　　 　　　 热即与疏转后有疮疹则轻既出不可疏利　　 　　　 已出诸证不一
　　 　　　 论热毒所起之由
　　 　　　 已出不可服油剂
　　 　　　 有发出有温出有解毒
　　 　　　 虽有热证大便如常过则不可再下　　 　　　 不可妄发妄下
　　 　　　 发热有时则应脏腑知其斑疮疹水疱脓疱　　 　　　 蕴热斑毒
　　 　　　 已出未匀
　　 　　　 未发令内消
　　 　　　 发热而痛
　　 　　　 出不快
　　 　　　 面青者逆
　　 　　　 身热而脉反迟
　　 　　　 非微汗则表不解
　　 　　　 既出不尽透透而不长血疱　　 　　　 未出可下已出不可下出已定当利其大小便　　 　　　 发有微盛
　　 　　　 热在表不可疏转
　　 　　　 出太盛
　　　　　 伤寒与疮疹同异
　　 　　　 未能辨认服升麻汤已发未发用胡荽酒　　 　　　 气匀即出快[396p]
　　 　　　 疮成脓疱烦躁
　　 　　　 身热耳尖脚梢冷腹内痛成块　　 　　　 爱护将理
　　 　　　 手足冷腹中硬为疮疹
　　 　　　 疮疹未见乃可疏利
　　 　　　 石壁经论疮疹歌
　　　　　 辨刘氏论转下张氏论用药　　 　 卷四百六十三
　　 　　 奇效良方　明·方贤
　　 　　　 疮疹热与诸般热不同
　　 　　　 出视轻重
　　 　　　 疏利与取转不同
　　 　　　 辨董汲指迷方论与钱氏活人书不同　　 　　　 方宜不同用药亦异
　　 　　　 戒失饥不可当风冷
　　 　　　 大热当利小便小热当解毒　　 　　　 小便赤濇心腹胀满
　　 　　　 先利而后出但解毒不可再利　　 　　　 烦躁而渴
　　 　　　 睡卧不安
　　 　　　 状如蚊蚤所啮毒盛色黑
　　 　　　 悞服凉药冰伏
　　 　　　 便血粪黑睡而不醒
　　 　　　 已出而腹账[397p]
　　 　　　 当下当救里
　　 　　　 既下惧太早
　　 　　　 误下证
　　 　　　 疮疹有当大便过有当温有当下　　 　　　 或吐或泻或不食
　　 　　　 疮疹皆多在表不可妄下
　　 　　　 陷伏倒靥
　　 　　　 黑陷耳骩反热
　　 　　　 黑有逆顺
　　 　　　 出迟朝夜啼哭
　　 　　　 凸凹生疮
　　　　　 大便如常
　　 　　　 悞服热药则损目冷药则夭伤　　 　　　 斑烂
　　 　　　 感寒与疮疹伏热混杂而发　　 　　　 郁毒不散
　　 　　　 乳婴与食孩用药不同
　　 　　　 本稀不可发表
　　 　　　 无凝滞则勿表勿下
　　 　　　 痂起能食
　　 　　　 黑餍而未发寒
　　 　　　 诸恶证
　　 　　　 先知节候阴阳脏腑虚实
　　 　　　 行房触犯烧赤朮猪甲
　　 　　　 初生服生地黄汁令不生疮　　 　　　 疮毒令胃烂便血[398p]
　　 　　　 余毒失解利则呕吐并诸杂证　　 　　　 预服油剂解毒
　　　　　 疹热出难大便不通小便如血或为痈身体破裂　　 　　　 误用巴豆则内虚而热不除　　 　　　 勿用巴豆水银轻粉
　　 　　　 热毒攻肝冲目
　　 　　　 疮后咳嗽胁痛
　　 　　　 伤寒热毒急宜发表
　　 　　　 余毒不尽烦渴胸满
　　 　　　 不结痂疕
　　 　　　 辨疮并冰疮入大肠
　　 　　　 结核肿毒
　　 　　　 冬温发斑如锦纹
　　 　　　 用百祥丸证
　　 　　　 疮后患目翳忌点药
　　 　　　 冬月预服三豆饮子
　　 　　　 疮入目防备法
　　 　　　 疮毒攻咽
　　 　　　 大小便不通
　　 　　　 乳婴药多反为累
　　 　　　 冬温宜先下毒
　　 　　　 便脓血
　　 　　　 脓汁不干
　　 　　　 入目用药
　　 　　　 余毒诸证
　　 　　　 消瘢痕[399p]
　　　　　 痘痈
　　 　　　 疮后发搐
　　　　　 疮后中地风证
　　　　　 已出狂叫喘呼
　　　　　 猪尾膏证
　　 　 卷四百六十四
　　 　　 家传痘疹心法　明·万全
　　 　　　 痘疹证似伤寒
　　 　　　 首尾不可汗下
　　 　　　 不可以日期论
　　 　　　 大人小儿富贵贫贱不同
　　 　　　 升麻葛根汤解
　　 　　　 顺逆
　　 　　　 变黑归肾
　　　　　 变黑有逆顺
　　　　　 诸痛痒疮皆属于心
　　 　　　 过饮冷水变生诸证
　　 　　　 钱氏陈氏立法用药同异
　　 　　　 补脾土泻肾水
　　 　　　 泻脓血痂皮水谷
　　 　　　 斑疹
　　 　　　 五行生死
　　 　　　 先哲格言
　　 　　　 或问
　　 　 卷四百六十五

　　 　　　 禁忌
　　 　 卷四百八十
　　 　　 痘疹论　清·聂久吾
　　 　　　 辟时医之谬
　　 　　　 白朮散豆蔻丸说
　　 　　　 论衄血
　　 　　　 论年长出痘
　　 　　　 或问五条
　　 　　　 麻疹四忌
　　 　　 疹科纂要　清·马之骐
　　 　　　 麻疹通论
　　 　　　 证治大略
　　 　　　 潮热证治
　　 　　　 伤风
　　 　　　 汗渴饮水
　　 　　　 烦躁
　　 　　　 谵语
　　　　　 欬嗽
　　 　　　 咽痛失音
　　 　　　 呕吐腹痛
　　 　　　 泄泻
　　 　　　 痢
　　 　　　 诸失血
　　 　　　 饮食疮毒
　　 　　　 痘疮后盖痘疹
　　 　　　 疫病发斑夹斑
　　 　　　 伤寒发斑瘾疹
　　　　　 孕妇麻疹发斑
　　 　　　 水痘证治[416p]
　　 　 卷四百八十一
　　 　　 痘科类编释意　清．翟良
　　 　　　 原痘论
　　 　　　 论气血并晰气血盈亏消长之理　　 　　　 部位论
　　 　　　 头面预肿渐肿论
　　 　　　 痘成功有次序色有递变不同论　　 　　　 形色论
　　 　　　 宁教有色而无形休教有形而无色论　　 　　　 虚实寒热不同辨
　　 　　　 评诸家明用药寒热要各得其宜　　 　　　 汗下论
　　 　　　 热不可尽除说
　　 　　　 解毒化毒论
　　 　　　 痘不为害惟毒为害论
　　　　　 痘有成色当就其成色而成就之治法不可执一论　　 　　　 气尊血分者生毒参阳位者死解　　 　　　 痘不以稀密分轻重说
　　 　　　 痘中疹子与正疹子丹毒斑点沙子不同论　　 　　　 痘不可与凡疮同治论
　　 　　　 痘疹不同论
　　 　　　 变黑归肾肾经留邪论
　　 　　　 首尾忌脑麝论[417p]
　　 　 卷四百八十二
　　 　　 痘科类编释意　清·翟良
　　 　　　 治痘始终杂证与痘证当分治论　　 　　　 治痘始终看法说
　　 　　　 痘不拘日期说
　　 　　　 痘证传变说
　　　　　 出长各经见证与传变成功形色不同之辨　　 　　　 就人以断痘之轻重说
　　 　　　 就人以定痘之治法说
　　 　　　 三等五要说
　　 　　　 痘有五善七恶说
　　 　　　 治痘总法
　　 　　　 初热三日证治
　　 　　　 论痘疮发热与伤寒不同
　　 　　　 出见三日证治
　　 　　　 调养禁忌
　　 　　　 避秽气
　　 　　　 起胀三日证治
　　 　　　 灌脓三日证治
　　 　　　 收靥三日证治
　　 　　　 结痂落痂证治
　　 　 卷四百八十三
　　　　 痘科类编释意　清·翟良
　　 　　 痘后余毒余证

　　 　 卷四百八十四
　　　　 痘疹经验良方　明·魏君用　　 　　　 预防
　　 　　　 遵岁气
　　 　　　 痘前十八犯
　　 　　　 痘疔方位所属
　　 　　　 认痘疔诀
　　 　　　 用银针手法
　　 　　　 发热
　　 　　　 见点
　　 　　　 稠密之处各有经络部分所属　　 　　　 起胀
　　 　　　 灌浆
　　 　　　 收靥余毒
　　 　 卷四百八十五
　　　　 救偏琐言　明·费启泰
　　 　　　 救偏总论
　　 　　　 原痘论
　　 　　　 论气
　　 　　　 论血
　　 　　　 治痘运掌赋
　　 　　　 推广规则录
　　 　　　 治痘须知大运论
　　 　　　 论治痘权宜[420p]
　　 　　　 治痘药性摘要赋
　　 　　　 发热论
　　 　　　 升发论
　　 　　　 疏表
　　 　　　 达里
　　 　 卷四百八十六
　　 　　 救偏琐言　明·费启泰
　　 　　　 痘有首尾疏达诀
　　 　　　 痘有不宜疏达诀
　　 　　　 放点证治准
　　 　　　 稀有内证
　　 　　　 密有充肥
　　 　　　 陷有毒滞
　　 　　　 绽有囊薄
　　 　　　 薄有浮衣
　　 　　　 平扁与不松辨
　　 　　　 气拘与毒绊辨
　　 　　　 娇红非血热辨
　　 　　　 血郁非气虚辨
　　 　　　 起胀证治准
　　 　　　 攻毒总诀
　　　　　 申明鼻衄
　　 　　　 申明舌刺咽干
　　 　　　 申明溺血
　　 　　　 申明大肠逼迫
　　 　　　 申明拂郁皮毛
　　 　　　 申明啼号不已
　　 　　　 堂壅遏日夜无眠
　　 　　　 申明痰迷上窍昏闷无声[421p]
　　 　　　 申明静躁无定愁容可掬
　　 　　　 申明骨节烦疼腰如被杖
　　 　　　 申明筋抽脉惕
　　 　　　 申明遍体炎炎
　　 　　　 申明四肢独冷
　　 　　　 申明通身汗涌
　　 　　　 申明头汗如蒸
　　 　　　 申明毒涌掀肿
　　 　　　 申明疙瘩块
　　　　　 申明预封预肿
　　 　　　 申明红丝繞目倒竖拳毛
　　 　　　 申明痘如蒙垢口秽喷人
　　 　　　 申明发始咬牙
　　 　　　 申明发始弄舌
　　 　　　 申明两颊通红痘无一点
　　 　　　 申明涌出如针
　　 　　　 申明黑陷歪斜
　　 　　　 申明紫背浮萍
　　 　　　 申明蚤斑
　　 　　　 申明贯珠攒簇怪痘
　　 　　　 申明恶色并治法
　　 　　　 申明四毒顶
　　 　　　 申明痘佳证恶
　　 　　　 申明痘白雄标
　　 　　　 申明飞浆
　　 　　　 申明泡涌[422p]
　　 　 卷四百八十七
　　 　　 救偏琐言　明·费启泰
　　 　　　 凉血撮要诀
　　 　　　 清火穷源论
　　 　　　 论行浆
　　 　　　 论补气

　　 　　　 论健胃

　　 　　　 论气虚作痒
　　 　　　 论脾虚作泻
　　 　　　 论痘变证有不常不古

　　 　　　 论血热作痒
　　 　　　 论热剧寒战

　　 　　　 论汗有补泻

　　 总论[425p]
　　 　 卷五百一
　　 　　 易经
　　 　　　 无妄卦
　　 　　 书经
　　 　　　 说命上
　　 　　 礼记
　　 　　　 曲礼下
　　 　　 周礼
　　 　　　 天官
　　 　　 春秋四传
　　 　　　 许世子止不尝药
　　 　　 黄帝素问
　　 　　　 四气调神大论篇
　　 　　　 生气通天论篇
　　 　　　 金匮真言论篇
　　 　　　 阴阳应象大论篇
　　 　　　 阴阳别论篇
　　 　　　 灵兰秘典论篇
　　 　　　 五脏别论篇
　　 　　　 移精变气论篇
　　 　　　 汤液醪醴论篇
　　 　　　 举痛论篇
　　 　　　 至真要大论篇
　　 　　　 着至教论篇
　　 　　　 示从容论篇
　　 　　　 疏五过论篇
　　 　　　 征四失论篇
　　 　　　 方盛衰论篇
　　 　　　 解精微论篇
　　 　　 灵枢经
　　 　　　 邪气脏腑病形[426p]
　　 　　　 根结
　　 　　　 官针
　　　　　 逆顺肥瘦
　　 　　　 顺气一日分为四时
　　 　　　 贼风
　　 　　 扁鹊难经
　　　　　 十二难
　　 　　　 十三难
　　 　　　 六十一难
　　 　　　 七十七难
　　 　　　 八十一难
　　 　　 金匮要略　汉·张机
　　 　　　 脏腑经络先后病脉证
　　 　　 褚氏遗书　齐·褚澄
　　 　　　 除疾
　　 　　　 审微
　　 　　　 辨书
　　 　　 物理论　梁·阳泉
　　 　　　 论医
　　　　 隋书
　　 　　　 经籍志
　　 　　 千金方　唐·孙思邈
　　 　　　 论大医习业
　　 　　　 论大医精诚
　　 　　　 论治病略例
　　 　　　 论诊侯
　　 　　 东坡杂记　宋·苏轼
　　 　　　 求医诊脉
　　 　　　 医者以意用药
　　 　　 避暑录话　宋·叶梦得[427p]
　　 　　　 士大夫不可轻信医
　　 　　　 集方书
　　 　　 玉涧杂书　宋·叶梦得
　　 　　　 医不能起死人
　　　　 梦溪笔谈　宋·沈括
　　 　　　 用药不可不慎
　　　　 省心录　宋·林逋
　　 　　　 论医
　　　　 外科精要　宋·陈自明
　　 　　　 论医者更易良方
　　 　 卷五百二
　　 　　 珍珠囊指掌　元·李杲
　　 　　　 用药法
　　　　 此事难知　元·王好古
　　 　　　 医之可法
　　 　　 卫生宝鉴　元·罗天益
　　 　　　 福医治病
　　 　　 丹溪心法　元·朱震亨
　　 　　　 不治已病治未病论
　　 　　　 审察病机无失气宜论
　　　　　 能合色脉可以万全论
　　 　　 汤液本草　元·王好古
　　 　　　 察病轻重
　　 　　　 医之可法
　　 　　 医门群经辨论　明·吕复

　　 　　　 论医
　　　　 比事摘录
　　 　　　 医孝
　　　　 医先　明·王文禄
　　 　　　 论医
　　 　　 医学正传　明·虞抟
　　 　　　 或问
　　　　 明医杂着　明·王纶
　　 　　　 医论
　　 　　 柏斋三书
　　 　　　 治疗须法《素问》
　　 　　 原机启微　元·倪维德
　　 　　　 序
　　　　 医说　宋·张杲
　　 　　　 医药之难
　　 　　　 医通神明
　　 　　　 医不贪色
　　 　　　 隐医
　　 　　　 治病委之庸医比之不慈不孝　　　　 续医说　明·俞弁
　　 　　　 处方贵简
　　 　　　 医贵权变
　　　 卷五百三
　　 　　 吴文定公家藏集
　　 　　　 医僧庸妄治病速死
　　 　　 医学集成　明·傅滋
　　 　　　 医学须会群书之长
　　 　　 九灵山房集　元·戴良[429p]
　　 　　　 医儒同道
　　 　　 大学衍义补　明·丘浚
　　　　　 国设医学
　　 　　 本草衍义　宋·寇宗奭
　　 　　　 医有八要
　　 　　 本草类方　清·年希尧
　　 　　　 医不可用孟浪
　　 　　 古今医统　明·徐春甫
　　 　　　 慎疾慎医
　　 　　　 古医十四科
　　 　　　 时医
　　 　　　 巫医
　　 　　　 名医
　　 　　　 儒医
　　 　　　 五难
　　 　　　 医喻政
　　 　　　 论医
　　 　　　 裒方书
　　 　　　 一理贯通
　　 　　　 针灸药三者备为医之良
　　 　　　 庸医速报
　　 　　　 医业不精反为夭折
　　 　　　 用药活法
　　 　　 证治准绳　明·王肯堂
　　　　　 通论
　　 　　 医学入门　明·李梴
　　　　　 习医规格
　　 　　 万病回春　明·龚廷贤
　　 　　　 医家十要[430p]
　　　　　 病家十要
　　 　　　 医家病家通病
　　 　　 外科正宗　明·陈实功
　　 　　　 医家五戒十要
　　 　　 小儿卫生总微论方　宋·撰人不详　　 　　　 医工论
　　 　　 医宗必读　明·李中梓
　　 　　　 不失人情论
　　 　　　 行方智圆心小胆大论
　　 　　 本草经疏　明·缪希雍
　　 　　　 祝医五则
　　 　　 医门法律　清·喻昌
　　 　　　 治病
　　　　 寓意草　清·喻昌
　　 　　　 先议病后议药
　　　　　 议病式
　　　　 日知录　清·顾炎武
　　 　　 论医

Interlaced

古今图书集成医部全录 （清˙陈梦雷等编）前言

　　 陈梦雷，福建闽候人，在康熙年间中了进士，以后被授予编修等职。因为他性情直爽，又忠心耿直，得罪了一些人，所以被诬告而入狱，吃了十年官司，才被释放回家。他自以为太平无事了，谁知到雍正初又被莫名其妙地捉了去，最后死在牢狱中。在他自由在外的时候，搜集了世纪以前的全部医学文献，主编了《医部全录》这部我国最大的医学类书。　　本书系清代名医蒋廷锡等原著，刊行于年，是<古今图书集成>的一部分。原著卷，约千万字，是中国历代以来最大的一部医学类书。全书包括医经注释、诊断、各科疾病的理论经验，以及有关医学的艺文、记事和名医列传等。可供一般医务工作者阅读和参考。古今图书集成医部全录目录[1p]

Preface to the Complete Collection of Medical Works in Ancient and Modern Times

Chen Menglei, a native of Minhou in Fujian, passed the imperial examination during the Kangxi era and was later appointed to editorial positions. Due to his straightforward nature and unwavering loyalty, he offended some individuals, which led to false accusations and imprisonment. He endured ten years of legal battles before being released home. He believed that peace had returned, but unexpectedly, he was arrested again at the beginning of the Yongzheng era and ultimately died in prison. During his time outside, he collected all medical literature from a century earlier and compiled the "Complete Collection of Medical Works," the largest medical book in our country. This work is based on the original texts of renowned Qing dynasty physicians, such as Jiang Tingxi, published in the year, and is part of the "Complete Collection of Ancient and Modern Books." The original text comprises approximately ten million characters, making it the largest medical work throughout Chinese history. The book includes annotations of medical classics, diagnostics, theoretical experiences of various diseases, and related literary works, records, and biographies of famous physicians, serving as a resource for general medical practitioners.[1p]

　　　　　 问两手寸关弦疾脾弱火胜木旺土亏金烁当作何治　　　　　 脉当有神
　　　　　 察色脉以定吉凶

Breathing in and out, stabilizing the five organs’ pulses,
By feeling the lightness and heaviness of the fingers, determining the five organs.
The three sections and nine conditions that govern,
Holding the pulse,
The pulse must possess spirit.
The pulse reflects the balance of yin and yang,
From “Chuo Geng Lu” by Tao Jiucheng in the Yuan Dynasty,
Discussions on the pulse.
From “Dongyuan Shishu” by Li Gao in the Yuan Dynasty,
Discriminating the pulse,
On the regulation of color, pulse, and the harmony of the protective and nourishing forces.
On the method of holding the hand and feeling the messages.
Discussions on the disorders of the organs governed by the three sections.
The pulse classic of cooperation,
Deficiency and excess,
Inquiring about the two hands’ inch, guan, and xian,
Weak spleen, fire overpowering, wood flourishing, soil deficient, metal failing—what treatments should be applied?
The pulse ought to have spirit.
Observing color and pulse to determine fortune or misfortune.
When serious, illness advances.
Distinguishing the floating pulse leads to different disorders.
The right treatment for the three-section pulse.
From “Danxi Heart Method” by Zhu Zhenheng in the Yuan Dynasty,
The pulse resembles heaven and earth,
Able to combine color and pulse to attain wholeness.
Various discussions on pulse diagnosis,
The soggy and xian pulse.
From “Ge Zhi Yu Lun” by Zhu Zhenheng in the Yuan Dynasty.[18p]

The meaning of the pulse is not simply about change.
The pulse is based on the stomach’s qi.
Diagnosis differs from that of Shuhe.
Emphasis on both yin and yang.
Separating yin from yang.
Yin and yang interdepend, one suppressing the other.
When yin is absent, yang is also absent.
The pulse lacking roots has two interpretations.
Pulse is distinguished by channel and collateral.
In a year, the pulse representations cannot be observed again.
The pulse shows overactivity and control.
Differences exist between the pulse of the old and the young.
Diagnose based on the evidence rather than the pulse.
Rely on the pulse over the evidence.
Though seven diagnoses reveal the nine conditions, those who follow will not perish.
Chong, Yang, Taixi, and Taichong.
Dividing the ren and qi, the pulse methods are established.
Internal cause pulse.
External cause pulse.
Neither internal nor external cause pulse.
Deathly pulse.
Motion and stillness of the pulse.
Various pulse indications and contraindications.
The six essentials of medical principles. — Ming Dynasty, Zhang Sanxi.
In pulse diagnosis, the intention is paramount.
Location of the organs.
Women’s pulse.
Reflected pulse.[24p]

　　　　　 定流年夏脉则例

  • Heart pulse reveals wisdom
  • Heart pulse reveals disaster
  • Heart pulse reveals official misfortune and parental suffering
  • Heart pulse reveals loneliness
  • Heart pulse reveals poverty
  • Heart pulse reveals worry and shock
  • Heart pulse reveals women's promiscuity
  • Heart pulse signifies illness and death
  • Spring reveals heart pulse
  • Heart pulse reveals illness and death
  • Summer reveals heart pulse
  • Autumn reveals heart pulse
  • Winter reveals heart pulse
  • Establishing the year, summer pulse follows the pattern
  • Summer month aligns with the season's rhythm
  • Lung pulse reveals nobility
  • Lung pulse reveals dreams
  • Lung pulse reveals paternal nobility
  • Lung pulse reveals misfortune
  • Lung pulse reveals joy, spouses are harmonious
  • Lung pulse signifies low status and fondness for travel
  • Lung pulse signifies punishment and law
  • Lung pulse signifies lack of virtue
  • Lung pulse reveals a high-status wife
  • Lung pulse reveals filial mourning
  • Spring reveals lung pulse
  • Summer reveals lung pulse
  • Autumn reveals lung pulse
  • Winter reveals lung pulse[32p]

　　 　　　 定流年冬脉则例[33p]

Regulations for Determining Annual Trends in Autumn

The autumn moon follows the season and announces:

  • The kidney pulse indicates joy.
  • The kidney pulse indicates wealth.
  • The kidney pulse indicates longevity.
  • The kidney pulse indicates joy of pregnancy.
  • The kidney pulse indicates official positions and short life.
  • The kidney pulse indicates talent and wisdom.
  • The kidney pulse indicates joy in desires.
  • The kidney pulse indicates blessings and longevity.
  • The kidney pulse indicates disasters and diseases.
  • The kidney pulse indicates excessive lust.
  • The kidney pulse indicates great learning without achievement.
  • The kidney pulse indicates many disasters in old age.
  • The kidney pulse indicates lawsuits and illness.
  • The kidney pulse indicates death and calamities.
  • The kidney pulse, along with the life gate, indicates fortune in servants and carriages, both good and bad.
  • The kidney and life gate together indicate loss of wealth due to official mandates and major disasters.
  • The kidney pulse is not suitable for wives and concubines.
  • The kidney pulse suggests adverse effects on kin and offspring.
  • The kidney pulse indicates illness and the shortening of life.
  • The kidney pulse indicates cultivation for longevity, either long or short.

The kidney pulse in spring,
The kidney pulse in summer,
The kidney pulse in autumn,
The kidney pulse in winter,
Regulations for determining annual trends in winter.[33p]

Winter Month, Seasonal Observations

General Discussion on the Spleen Pulse
The Spleen Pulse shows joy.
The Spleen Pulse indicates achievement, allowing for official titles and wealth.
The Spleen Pulse reveals innate skill but no official position.
The Spleen Pulse denotes a noble wife and longevity.
The Spleen Pulse suggests low status.
The Spleen Pulse indicates disaster and danger.
The Spleen Pulse foresees trouble with earth-related calamities.
The Spleen Pulse suggests a malevolent death.
The Spleen Pulse reflects unrest in the household.
The Spleen Pulse indicates official positions and wealth.
The Spleen Pulse reveals profound principles.
The Spleen Pulse signifies calamity.

　　　　　 火门兼治于外者

　　　　　 南政北政[77p]

Five Elements of Qi
Final Qi
Wind corresponds to wood, the liver is sour, treats with needles.
Heat corresponds to fire, the heart is bitter, induces sweating.
Dampness corresponds to earth, the spleen is sweet, removes needles.
Dryness corresponds to metal, the lungs are spicy, clears with needles.
Cold corresponds to water, the kidneys are salty, bends needles.
Great cold corresponds to the initial Qi of the child above.
Spring equinox corresponds to the second Qi of the rabbit above.
Lesser fullness corresponds to the third Qi of the snake above.
Great heat corresponds to the fourth Qi of the horse above.
Autumn equinox corresponds to the fifth Qi of the rooster above.
Lesser snow corresponds to the final Qi of the pig above.
Wind treatment method.
Heat treatment method.
Dampness treatment method.
Fire treatment method.
Dryness treatment method.
Cold treatment method.
Wind entry is treated solely within.
Heat entry is treated solely without.
Damp entry is treated both within and without.
Fire entry is treated both within and without.
Dry entry is first treated within, then treated without.
Cold entry is first treated without, then treated within.
From the "Ten Treatises of Dongyuan," Yuan Dynasty, by Li Gao.
Southern governance, Northern governance.[77p]

The Classic Texts on Ear Disorders

  1. "Jia Yi Jing" – Jin Dynasty, Huangfu Mi

    • Kidney Qi connects to the ears
    • Ear burns and withers

  2. "Ren Zhai Zhi Zhi Fang" – Song Dynasty, Yang Shiying

    • Deafness

  3. "Chuang Yang Quan Shu" – Jin Dynasty, Dou Hanqing

    • Ear wind poison
    • Ear gate abscess
    • Ear root abscess
    • Hair of the ear
    • Stone sore

  4. "Ji Sheng Fang" – Song Dynasty, Yan Yonghe

    • Discussion on ear treatments

  5. "He Jian Liu Shu" – Jin Dynasty, Liu Wansong

    • Deafness
    • Tinnitus

  6. "Dong Yuan Shi Shu" – Yuan Dynasty, Li Gao

    • Sounds of the ear flute
    • Tinnitus and deafness
    • Ears are associated with the kidney and the lungs

  7. "Dan Xi Xin Fa" – Yuan Dynasty, Zhu Zhenheng

    • Deafness
    • Tinnitus
    • Ear swelling and pain

  8. "Wei Sheng Bao Jian" – Yuan Dynasty, Luo Tianyi

    • Deafness
    • Sudden deafness
    • Difficulty hearing
    • Sore in the ear

  9. "Shi Yi De Xue Fang" – Yuan Dynasty, Wei Yilin[94p]

General Discussion on Tinnitus and Deafness[95p]

　　　　　 阴虚耳聋
　　　　　 气闭耳聋
　　　　　 肝火耳聋
　　　　　 痰火耳聋
　　　　　 气虚耳聋
　　　　　 风热耳聋
　　　　　 虚聋
　　　　　 肝火耳聋
　　　　 古今医统　明·徐春甫
　　　　　 耳聋有六候
　　　　　 耳聋耳鸣属热者多
　　　　　 气虚耳聋当见于大病之后　　　　　 耳聋当以通气开郁为主
　　　　　 耳聋治法宜泻南方补北方　　 　　 明医杂着　明·王纶
　　　　　 耳鸣
　　　　　 耳疮
　　 　　 医贯　明·赵献可
　　 　　　 论耳诸病
　　 　　　 耳疮
　　　　　 脓耳

　　 　　　 论耳

　　 　　　 耳内疮
　　　　　 耳后疽
　　　　　 耳根毒
　　 　　 医方考　明·吴昆
　　　　　 耳病方论[96p]

           Yin deficiency hearing loss
           Qi obstruction hearing loss
           Liver fire hearing loss
           Phlegm fire hearing loss
           Qi deficiency hearing loss
           Wind-heat hearing loss
           Deficient hearing
           Liver fire hearing loss
           Ancient and modern medical principles by Xu Chunfu in the Ming Dynasty
           Hearing loss has six conditions
           Hearing loss and tinnitus often belong to heat
           Qi deficiency hearing loss should occur after a major illness
           Hearing loss should primarily focus on circulating qi and relieving stagnation
           For treating hearing loss, it is advisable to drain from the south and supplement from the north
           Medical Miscellany by Wang Lun in the Ming Dynasty

Medical Introduction by Li Zhan from the Ming Dynasty
Division of Eyes: Internal and External
Five Wheels and Eight Borders
White pertains to the Lungs; Black pertains to the Liver
Inner and Outer Canthi pertain to the Heart and Small Intestine
Upper and Lower Eyelids pertain to the Stomach and Spleen
Pupil pertains to Kidney Water
Eight Borders' Locations
Women and Children
Acute Redness, Swelling, Pain, and Itching
Pterygium, Tears, and Blurred Vision belong to the Exterior
Blurred vision and sensitivity to light
Internal Obstructions with Dark Flowers and Obscured Pupils
Myopia indicates Yin Deficiency; Hyperopia indicates Yang Deficiency
Cold Tears and Eye Pain

Reverse order creates opacity

　　 　　　 漏睛脓血

　　　　 证治准绳　明·王肯堂
　　 　　　 五轮
　　 　　　 八廓
　　 　　　 开导说
　　 　　　 点服药说[105p]

Leaky eyes with pus and blood
Crab-like protruding eyes
Wind pulls at the eyelids
Blood floods the pupils
Squinting amidst flying dust
The heavens move with red eyes in fury
The heavens move with red eyes
Rotten strings and windblown eyelids
Storms make the guest feel hot
The eyelids are stiff, and the eyes ache
Pain like a needle prick
The pupils are dry and missing
Wind itches unbearably
Yellow membrane surges upward
Red membrane droops downward
Growths arise within the eyelids
Blood-filled sacs cloud the vision
Children with malnutrition and eye troubles
Morning brings pain
Afternoon leads to dimness
Women experience a reversal of blood flow
Pain extreme, detests cold
Getting up and sitting down brings blossoms
Flowing blood is the key to treating the eyes
Dissipating heat is essential for eye treatment
Swollen pain and dimness
Evidence and Treatment Principles - Ming - Wang Kentang
Five wheels
Eight directions
Guidance on discussions
Instructions for medication[105p]

　　 　　　 钩割针烙说
　　 　　　 论目痛
　　 　　　 天行赤热
　　 　　　 暴风客热
　　 　　　 火胀大头
　　 　　　 羞明怕热
　　 　　　 睑硬睛疼
　　　　　 赤痛如邪
　　 　　　 气眼
　　 　　　 痛如针刺
　　 　　　 热结膀胱
　　 　　　 大小雷头风
　　 　　　 左右偏头风
　　 　　　 阴邪风
　　 　　　 阳邪风
　　 　　　 卒脑风
　　 　　　 巅顶风
　　 　　　 游风
　　　　　 邪风
　　 　 卷一百四十二
　　　　 证治准绳　明·王肯堂
　　 　　　 论目赤
　　 　　　 瘀血灌睛
　　 　　　 血灌瞳神
　　 　　　 色似臙脂
　　 　　　 赤脉贯睛
　　 　　　 赤丝乱脉
　　 　　　 目珠俱青
　　 　　　 论目肿胀
　　 　　　 肿胀如杯
　　 　　　 形如虾座
　　 　　　 状如鱼泡[106p]

On Eye Pain
The heavens move with heat,
The violent wind brings warmth,
Fire causes swelling of the head,
Shame and brightness fear heat,
The eyelids are hard and the eyes ache,
Red pain feels like evil,
The eye’s Qi,
Pain is like a needle's prick,
Heat binds the bladder,
Large and small headaches,
Left and right headaches,
Yin evil wind,
Yang evil wind,
Sudden stroke,
Wind at the crown,
Wandering wind,
Evil wind.

On Eye Redness
Stagnant blood fills the eyes,
Blood fills the pupil,
Color resembles rouge,
Red veins penetrate the eye,
Red threads disturb the veins,
The eyeball is blue.

On Eye Swelling
Swelling is like a cup,
Form resembles a shrimp,
Appearance like a fish bladder.[106p]

　　 　　　 鹘眼凝睛
　　 　　　 因风成毒
　　 　　　 旋螺泛起
　　 　　　 旋螺尖起
　　 　　　 神珠自胀
　　 　　　 珠突出眶
　　 　　　 论目痒
　　 　　　 痒若虫行
　　　　　 论外障
　　 　　　 黄膜上冲
　　 　　　 赤膜下垂
　　 　　　 凝脂瞖
　　 　　　 花瞖白陷
　　 　　　 蟹睛
　　 　　　 斑脂瞖
　　 　　　 黄油障
　　 　　　 状如悬胆
　　 　　　 玉粒分经
　　 　　　 银星独见
　　 　　　 聚开障
　　 　　　 聚星障
　　 　　　 垂帘障
　　 　　　 涌波瞖
　　 　　　 逆顺障
　　 　　　 阴阳翳
　　 　　　 玛瑙内伤
　　 　　　 连珠外翳
　　 　　　 剑脊翳
　　 　　　 冰瑕瞖
　　 　　　 圆翳外障
　　 　　　 水晶障
　　 　　　 鱼鳞障
　　 　　　 马蝗积[107p]

Hawk-eyed and sharp-eyed,
In the wind, they become venomous.
The spiral shell emerges,
With the tip of the spiral rising.
The divine pearl swells,
As the pearl protrudes from the socket.
Discussing eye itch,
It itches as if bugs are crawling.
Discussing external obstruction,
Yellow films surge upward,
While red membranes droop down.
Creacting fat blockages,
Flowery blockages invade white.
Crab eyes and
Spotted fatty blockages,
Yellow oil obstructions,
In appearance like a suspended gallbladder.
Jade grains divide the channels,
Silver stars are seen alone.
Gathering open obstructions,
Gathering star obstructions,
Hanging curtain obstructions,
Rising wave blockages,
Opposing and following obstructions,
Yin and Yang veils,
Agate inner injuries,
Connected pearl outer veils,
Sword spine veils,
Icy blemishes,
Round veils of external obstructions,
Crystal obstructions,
Fish scale obstructions,
Locust accumulations.[107p]

　　 　　　 胞肉胶粘[109p]

The text appears to be a collection of diagnostic terms and descriptions related to eye conditions, along with various symptoms and phenomena observed in the eyes. Here is the translation:

  Crescent moon encroaches on the eye  
  Jujube flower barrier  
  White haze with yellow center  
  Black flower dimming  
  Volume One Hundred Forty-Three  
  Evidence and Treatment Standards - Ming Dynasty, Wang Kengtang  
  Five winds transform into internal obstacles  
  Pupil is dilated  
  Pupil is tight and small  
  Pupil is tilted  
  Discussing blurred vision  
  Vision is dim and unclear  
  Yellow eye with unclear vision  
  Dryness causes blurred vision  
  Rising and sitting induces distortion  
  Fireflies fill the eyes  
  Sudden blindness  
  Blue blindness  
  Sparrow blindness  
  Genuine eye ointment damage  
  Ointment injures the pearl  
  Divine fluid is about to dry  
  Wheel turns at the gate  
  Both eyes are clear  
  Divine pearl is about to reflect  
  Pupil is turned back  
  Blue and yellow emerge  
  Energy moves in the pearl  
  Inverted eyelashes and clenched hairs  
  Fierce tightness in the eyes  
  Flesh sticky to the wheel  
  Tissue glued together

---[109p]

　　　　　 夹喉疽
　　 　　　 结喉痈

Fingers and toes falling off,
Nails falling off,
Blood flowing between the fingers,
A bulge in the palm,
Meat blocks at the calves,
Fingers growing under the feet.

　　　　　 古今中风辨
　　　　　 论中风属风

　　 　　　 论真中风
　　 　　　 论续命等汤

　　 　　　 非风论正名
　　 　　　 论有邪无邪
　　 　　　 论肝邪
　　 　　　 论气虚

Hejian Six Writings by Liu Wansu of the Jin Dynasty

  • Difficulty in Defecation

Dongyuan Ten Writings by Li Gao of the Yuan Dynasty

  • On Constipation
  • If blocked, urination is impossible
  • Alcohol toxicity leads to urine being red and thick; the Wu Ling San is suitable

Suhui Collection by Wang Lu of the Yuan Dynasty

  • On the Origins of Urination

Suhui Collection by Wang Lu of the Yuan Dynasty

  • Dryness and Constipation
  • On the Pills for Spleen Issues
  • Discussion on Forbidden Practices for Smooth Defecation
  • No prohibition on Urination
  • Difficulty in Urination

Medical Essentials by Yu Tuan of the Ming Dynasty

  • On Constipation and Secrecy
  • Urine being red and thick

Essentials of Diagnosis and Treatment by Dai Sigong of the Ming Dynasty

  • Constipation
  • Urinary Retention
  • Frequent Urination Issues

Miscellaneous Writings by Wang Lun of the Ming Dynasty

  • No prohibition on frequent urination

Medical Overview by Lou Ying of the Ming Dynasty

  • Urinary Retention
  • Not advantageous

Thousand Gold Prescriptions - Tang Dynasty, Sun Simiao

  • Vomiting blood
  • Nasal bleeding

Living Human Book - Song Dynasty, Zhu Gong

  • Vomiting blood due to cold damage
  • Nasal bleeding due to cold damage

  • Bleeding from the nose

  • Upward overflow
  • Nasal bleeding
  • Blood in stools

  • Bleeding from the nose

  • Vomiting blood
  • Coughing up blood
  • Coughing blood
  • Nosebleeds
  • Blood in urine
  • Blood in stools
  • Intestinal wind and toxic blood

Pingzhi Huicui - Yuan Dynasty, Zhu Zhenheng

  • Blood in stools
  • Blood is linked to yin, difficult to achieve yet easily lost theory

  • General distinctions
  • Vomiting blood
  • Coughing up blood
  • Spitting blood [220p]

On Malaria: Not Caused by Spleen Cold or Spirits

On Curing Malaria

From the "Ten Books of Dongyuan" by Li Gao, Yuan Dynasty:

  • Summer injuries lead to malaria in autumn.
  • Treatment should follow the seasons.
  • Discusses malaria related to the five organs.
  • Discusses malaria related to the six meridians.

From the "Heart Method of Danxi" by Zhu Zhenheng, Yuan Dynasty:

  • Symptoms and treatment of malaria.

From "Extra Discussions on Grit and Reality" by Zhu Zhenheng, Yuan Dynasty:

  • Treatise on malaria.

From "Key Points in Diagnosis and Treatment" by Dai Sigong, Ming Dynasty:

  • Symptoms and treatment of malaria.

From "Miscellaneous Writings of Ming Medicine" by Wang Lun, Ming Dynasty:

  • Symptoms and treatment of malaria.

Volume 289

From "Introduction to Medicine" by Li Zhan, Ming Dynasty:

  • Differentiating Yin and Yang.
  • Distinguishing cold and heat.
  • Clarifying the six meridians.
  • Sensitivity to external influences.
  • Treatment through sweat, vomiting, and purging.
  • Deficiency and exhaustion.
  • Phlegm-related conditions.
  • Food stagnation.
  • Causes of malaria.
  • Concurrent dysentery.
  • Variations of cold damage.
  • Symptoms resembling malaria.
  • Predominance of heat and insignificance of cold.[233p]

　　 　　 方[270p]

Introduction to Medicine - Ming Dynasty, Li Zhan
Water cold clashes
Understanding counterflows, distinguishing names
Differentiating symptoms of yin and yang
Identifying illness as vacuity or repletion
Fire burns due to yin vacuity
Overexertion injures the spleen
Chronic illness
Injury from improper diet
Phlegm and qi
Mistakes in purging

Key Points of Syndrome and Treatment - Ming Dynasty, Dai Sigong
General discussion of syndrome and treatment

Six Texts of Cold Damage - Ming Dynasty, Tao Hua
Discussion on symptoms and distinguishing names

Medical Canon from Ancient to Modern - Ming Dynasty, Xu Chunfu
Symptoms have distinctions
Cough and counterflow belong to fire
Illness must be marked and differentiated
Treatment should lower fire and regulate qi
Methods of vomiting and purging achieve quick results

Guidelines for Symptoms and Treatment - Ming Dynasty, Wang Kentang
General discussion

Huangdi's Plain Questions[336p]

　　 　　　 阴阳别论

　　 　　　 漏下

急惊 (Sudden fright)

惊搐 (Fright-induced convulsions)
小儿用药不宜峻厉 (Medications for children should not be harsh)
惊后目动咬牙 (Teeth grinding and eye movement after fright)
出痘发搐 (Convulsions following smallpox)

　　 　 卷四百三十六
　　 　　 方
　　 　 卷四百三十七
　　 　　 单方
　　 　　 针灸[376p]

Body heat with yellow diarrhea and thirst should be treated with cool agents.
Cold limbs with green diarrhea and no thirst should be treated with warm medicine.
Warm limbs with yellow and white diarrhea resembling thirst indicate a combination of cold and heat diseases.
Retention of food, abdominal pain, and the following prohibitions:
Vomiting;
Cold vomiting;
Hot vomiting;
Poisonous gas vomiting;
Breast injury vomiting;
Diarrhea;
Cold diarrhea;
Hot diarrhea;
Food injury diarrhea;
Shock diarrhea;
Acute diarrhea;
Chronic diarrhea;
Dinner diarrhea.

Principles of Diagnosis and Treatment by Wang Kentang, Ming Dynasty

Spleen

  • Weak spleen often leads to fatigue
  • Accumulated food
  • Food retention causing cold and heat
  • Food retention causing dysentery
  • Nine conditions of accumulated illness that can be treated
  • Six conditions that cannot be treated
  • Accumulation
  • Milk accumulation
  • Food accumulation
  • Qi accumulation
  • Accumulation within the spleen
  • Shock accumulation
  • Accumulation of deficiency
  • Accumulation of excess
  • Abdominal masses
  • Spleen blockages

　　 　　 痘疹心传必效良方　宋·沈氏　　 　　　 有余不足分治

Lesions appear with heat unresolved
Observation of pox to determine fortune or misfortune
Sparsity and density
Deficiency and excess

　　 　　　 痘疔
　　 　　　 黑陷
　　 　　　 紫红灰白二证

　　 　　 奇效良方　明·方贤
　　 　　　 疮疹论序
　　 　　　 论疮疹
　　 　　　 五脏各有一证
　　 　　　 论日数
　　 　　　 出于心则先惊搐
　　 　　　 似出不出
　　 　　　 出有逆顺
　　 　　　 出迟有数证
　　 　　　 论诸热失治变为疮疹候
　　 　　　 作搐
　　 　　　 论疏利
　　 　　　 论表出与温里不同
　　 　　　 诸疮痘肤疹[395p]

Here is the translation of the provided Classical Chinese text:

  • Reverse effects manifest
  • Death symptoms
  • Ulceration
  • Difficult symptoms
  • Violate prohibitions
  • Feverishness
  • Persistent sores
  • Tremors
  • Scab falling
  • Residual toxins
  • Many ailments post-pox
  • Post-pox conditioning
  • Women's pox
  • Pregnant women's pox
  • Rashes treatise
  • West River Moon
  • Treating rashes and miscellaneous diseases
  • Volume 462
  • Remarkable effective remedies by Ming Dynasties' Fang Xian
  • Treatise on sores and rashes preface
  • Treatise on sores and rashes
  • Each of the five organs has a symptom
  • Discussing the duration of days
  • If arising from the heart, then pre-embarrassment
  • Appears to emerge but doesn't fully
  • The emergence has reverse and sequential forms
  • Delayed emergence has specific symptoms
  • Discussing changing heat conditions into sore symptoms
  • Causes of convulsions
  • Discussing regulating and benefiting
  • Discussing differences between superficial and internal conditions
  • Various sores, pox, and skin rashes.[395p]

　　 　　　 热即与疏转后有疮疹则轻既出不可疏利　　 　　　 已出诸证不一
　　 　　　 论热毒所起之由
　　 　　　 已出不可服油剂
　　 　　　 有发出有温出有解毒
　　 　　　 虽有热证大便如常过则不可再下　　 　　　 不可妄发妄下
　　 　　　 发热有时则应脏腑知其斑疮疹水疱脓疱　　 　　　 蕴热斑毒
　　 　　　 已出未匀
　　 　　　 未发令内消
　　 　　　 发热而痛
　　 　　　 出不快
　　 　　　 面青者逆
　　 　　　 身热而脉反迟
　　 　　　 非微汗则表不解
　　 　　　 既出不尽透透而不长血疱　　 　　　 未出可下已出不可下出已定当利其大小便　　 　　　 发有微盛
　　 　　　 热在表不可疏转
　　 　　　 出太盛
　　　　　 伤寒与疮疹同异
　　 　　　 未能辨认服升麻汤已发未发用胡荽酒　　 　　　 气匀即出快[396p]

Fever, when accompanied by rashes, indicates a light condition. Once manifested, it should not be dealt with carelessly or hastily.

The reasons for the emergence of heat toxins are diverse.

Once the symptoms appear, oil-based remedies should be avoided.

There are instances of eruptions, warmth, and detoxification.

Even with heat symptoms, if bowel movements remain normal, one should not purge again. Reckless treatment can lead to adverse outcomes.

When fever appears at intervals, one should be aware of its association with lesions, rashes, vesicles, and pustules, indicating accumulated heat and toxins.

Once manifested, symptoms may still be unbalanced; they have not properly resolved internally.

When fever is present along with pain, it does not subside quickly.

A greenish complexion suggests a counterflow of energy.

A hot body but a slow pulse indicates that, unless there is slight sweating, the exterior remains unresolved.

If symptoms have emerged but are not entirely resolved, they can still linger and may not evolve into blood blisters.

If there are no symptoms, treatment may proceed; if symptoms have manifested, they should not be hastily treated. Once established, one should encourage proper bowel movements.

Fever may vary in intensity.

Heat at the surface should not be neglected, especially if it is strong.

In cases similar to febrile diseases and rashes, one must identify and treat appropriately; if unsure, herbs like Schizonepeta or cilantro wine should be used.

When energy flows smoothly, it indicates a quick resolution.[396p]

　　 　　　 疮成脓疱烦躁
　　 　　　 身热耳尖脚梢冷腹内痛成块　　 　　　 爱护将理
　　 　　　 手足冷腹中硬为疮疹
　　 　　　 疮疹未见乃可疏利
　　 　　　 石壁经论疮疹歌
　　　　　 辨刘氏论转下张氏论用药　　 　 卷四百六十三
　　 　　 奇效良方　明·方贤
　　 　　　 疮疹热与诸般热不同
　　 　　　 出视轻重
　　 　　　 疏利与取转不同
　　 　　　 辨董汲指迷方论与钱氏活人书不同　　 　　　 方宜不同用药亦异
　　 　　　 戒失饥不可当风冷
　　 　　　 大热当利小便小热当解毒　　 　　　 小便赤濇心腹胀满
　　 　　　 先利而后出但解毒不可再利　　 　　　 烦躁而渴
　　 　　　 睡卧不安
　　 　　　 状如蚊蚤所啮毒盛色黑
　　 　　　 悞服凉药冰伏
　　 　　　 便血粪黑睡而不醒
　　 　　　 已出而腹账[397p]

Wounds have turned into pus-filled sores, causing restlessness. The body is hot, ears cold at the tips, feet cold, and there is pain like a lump in the abdomen. Care must be taken. The hands and feet are cold, and the abdomen is hard due to sores and rashes. If the rash is not visibly present, one may proceed with laxatives. The stone wall contains treatises and a song on sores and rashes, differentiating between Liu’s theories and Zhang’s use of medication.

In volume 463: miraculous effects and good prescriptions from the Ming Dynasty, by Fang Xian.

Sores and rashes caused by heat are different from various other types of heat. Evaluate their severity. Laxatives differ from those used to spur movement. Distinguish between Dong Ji’s guidance and Qian’s book on healing people, as the prescriptions should differ.

Avoid hunger and exposure to cold winds. Severe heat requires promoting urination; moderate heat requires detoxification. If urine is red and there's abdominal swelling, first promote elimination and then detox; avoid excessive laxatives.

Restlessness and thirst arise. Sleep is restless, with conditions like being bitten by mosquitoes or fleas, the poison strong and color dark. Administer cool medicines cautiously.

If there is blood in the stool and it appears black, there may be unconsciousness. If already released, but the abdomen is swollen.[397p]

　　 　　　 当下当救里
　　 　　　 既下惧太早
　　 　　　 误下证
　　 　　　 疮疹有当大便过有当温有当下　　 　　　 或吐或泻或不食
　　 　　　 疮疹皆多在表不可妄下
　　 　　　 陷伏倒靥
　　 　　　 黑陷耳骩反热
　　 　　　 黑有逆顺
　　 　　　 出迟朝夜啼哭
　　 　　　 凸凹生疮
　　　　　 大便如常
　　 　　　 悞服热药则损目冷药则夭伤　　 　　　 斑烂
　　 　　　 感寒与疮疹伏热混杂而发　　 　　　 郁毒不散
　　 　　　 乳婴与食孩用药不同
　　 　　　 本稀不可发表
　　 　　　 无凝滞则勿表勿下
　　 　　　 痂起能食
　　 　　　 黑餍而未发寒
　　 　　　 诸恶证
　　 　　　 先知节候阴阳脏腑虚实
　　 　　　 行房触犯烧赤朮猪甲
　　 　　　 初生服生地黄汁令不生疮　　 　　　 疮毒令胃烂便血[398p]

At this moment, it is urgent to save;
Stopping too early brings fear,
Which mistakenly leads to treatment.
Rashes may occur with bowel movements, during warmth, or suddenly;
They can manifest as vomiting, diarrhea, or loss of appetite.
Rashes are often superficial and should not be hastily treated.
Hideous marks and dark sores can lead to fever.
Dark conditions may show both reversal and progress.
Delayed occurrences manifest through day and night cries.
Swelling and sores appear.
Bowel movements remain normal.
If hot medicines are taken, it harms the eyes; cold medicines can lead to untimely harm.
Spots may rot.
Catching a chill mixed with rashes invokes heat, causing toxins to remain unresolved.
Medications for infants and children must differ.
What is inherently rare should not be forced out.
If there is no stagnation, do not force outward treatment or purging.
Scabs can arise while still able to eat.
If black and retentive but not yet showing cold symptoms,
Beware of various adverse conditions.
First, know the seasonal signs and the balance of yin and yang within the organs—both strengths and weaknesses.
Engaging in sexual activity irritates the condition, similar to burn of red herb and pig's hoof.
Newborns taking raw Rehmannia juice prevents sores from forming;
Deep sores can poison and cause the stomach to rot, leading to bloody stools.[398p]

　　 　　　 余毒失解利则呕吐并诸杂证　　 　　　 预服油剂解毒
　　　　　 疹热出难大便不通小便如血或为痈身体破裂　　 　　　 误用巴豆则内虚而热不除　　 　　　 勿用巴豆水银轻粉
　　 　　　 热毒攻肝冲目
　　 　　　 疮后咳嗽胁痛
　　 　　　 伤寒热毒急宜发表
　　 　　　 余毒不尽烦渴胸满
　　 　　　 不结痂疕
　　 　　　 辨疮并冰疮入大肠
　　 　　　 结核肿毒
　　 　　　 冬温发斑如锦纹
　　 　　　 用百祥丸证
　　 　　　 疮后患目翳忌点药
　　 　　　 冬月预服三豆饮子
　　 　　　 疮入目防备法
　　 　　　 疮毒攻咽
　　 　　　 大小便不通
　　 　　　 乳婴药多反为累
　　 　　　 冬温宜先下毒
　　 　　　 便脓血
　　 　　　 脓汁不干
　　 　　　 入目用药
　　 　　　 余毒诸证
　　 　　　 消瘢痕[399p]

Excessive toxins that have not been resolved lead to vomiting and various mixed symptoms. Preemptively taking oil preparations can detoxify.

Rashes with fever, difficulty in defecation, and blood-like urine; or the presence of boils and body ruptures. Misuse of colocynthis will result in internal deficiency and heat unrelieved. Avoid using colocynthis, mercury, or light powder.

Heat toxins invade the liver and affect the eyes.

Coughing and side pain after sores.

In cases of cold-induced fever with urgent heat toxins, it's essential to release the exterior.

Persistent remaining toxins cause thirst and chest fullness.

No scabbing or sores healing.

Differentiate between types of sores and ice sores entering the large intestine.

Tubercular swellings and toxicity.

Winter warmth presents rashes resembling brocade patterns.

Use Baixiang pills for related symptoms.

Post-sore eye problems should avoid topical medications.

In winter, preemptively take San Dou drink.

Preventive measures for eye infections from sores.

Sore toxicity attacks the throat.

Urination and defecation difficulties.

Excessive medicines for infants can lead to complications.

In cases of winter warmth, it’s best to clear toxins first.

Discharge of pus mixed with blood.

Pus not drying.

Medications for eye conditions.

Symptoms of remaining toxins.

Eliminate scar tissue.[399p]

　　　　　 痘痈
　　 　　　 疮后发搐
　　　　　 疮后中地风证
　　　　　 已出狂叫喘呼
　　　　　 猪尾膏证
　　 　 卷四百六十四
　　 　　 家传痘疹心法　明·万全
　　 　　　 痘疹证似伤寒
　　 　　　 首尾不可汗下
　　 　　　 不可以日期论
　　 　　　 大人小儿富贵贫贱不同
　　 　　　 升麻葛根汤解
　　 　　　 顺逆
　　 　　　 变黑归肾
　　　　　 变黑有逆顺
　　　　　 诸痛痒疮皆属于心
　　 　　　 过饮冷水变生诸证
　　 　　　 钱氏陈氏立法用药同异
　　 　　　 补脾土泻肾水
　　 　　　 泻脓血痂皮水谷
　　 　　　 斑疹
　　 　　　 五行生死
　　 　　　 先哲格言
　　 　　　 或问
　　 　 卷四百六十五
　　　　 家传痘疹心法　明·万全
　　 　　　 治痘凡例
　　 　　　 药性主治及修制法[400p]

Smallpox and Boils

After the sore, convulsions appear;
After the sore, symptoms of wind in the ground.
Has emerged with wild cries and gasping;
Symptoms similar to that of pig's tail balm.

Volume 464
Family Transmission of Smallpox Heart Method – Ming Dynasty, Wan Quan

Symptoms of smallpox resemble those of typhus;
Sweating and purging should not be done at the beginning or end;
The date cannot be used to judge the condition;
Adults and children, the rich and poor differ greatly.

Sichuan herb soup relieves it;
Proceeding and reversing,
Changing black returns to the kidney;
The change to black has both reverse and forward elements;

All pain, itching, and sores belong to the heart;
Excessive consumption of cold water leads to various symptoms;
The methods of the Qian and Chen families differ in usage;
Tonify the spleen while draining kidney water;
Drain pus, blood, scabs, and food;

Rashes;
The five elements of life and death;
Maxims of the ancients;
Sometimes questioned.

Volume 465
Family Transmission of Smallpox Heart Method – Ming Dynasty, Wan Quan

General principles for treating smallpox;
Medicinal properties, main treatments, and preparation methods.[400p]

Volume 467
Family Transmitted Principles of Smallpox - Ming Dynasty, Wanquan [401p]

　　 　　　 始终
　　 　　　 发热

  • Adhesion
  • Ambush
  • Stool
  • Hands and feet
  • Head and face
  • Pox and sores
  • Erupting blisters
  • Erupting without transparency
  • Yang toxicity
  • Propitious or ominous eruptions
  • Infusion evidence and treatment
  • Do not form pus[412p]

　　 　 卷四百八十一
　　 　　 痘科类编释意　清．翟良
　　 　　　 原痘论
　　 　　　 论气血并晰气血盈亏消长之理　　 　　　 部位论
　　 　　　 头面预肿渐肿论
　　 　　　 痘成功有次序色有递变不同论　　 　　　 形色论
　　 　　　 宁教有色而无形休教有形而无色论　　 　　　 虚实寒热不同辨
　　 　　　 评诸家明用药寒热要各得其宜　　 　　　 汗下论
　　 　　　 热不可尽除说
　　 　　　 解毒化毒论
　　 　　　 痘不为害惟毒为害论
　　　　　 痘有成色当就其成色而成就之治法不可执一论　　 　　　 气尊血分者生毒参阳位者死解　　 　　　 痘不以稀密分轻重说
　　 　　　 痘中疹子与正疹子丹毒斑点沙子不同论　　 　　　 痘不可与凡疮同治论
　　 　　　 痘疹不同论
　　 　　　 变黑归肾肾经留邪论
　　 　　　 首尾忌脑麝论[417p]

Expressing tranquility and restlessness, with a sorrowful face that can be touched.
The joints are troubled and painful, the waist feels beaten.
The muscles are tense and the veins alert.
The body is overwhelmingly hot.
The limbs are singularly cold.
Sweat pours from the whole body.
Sweat on the head is like steam.
Poison surges, causing swelling.
There are lumps and bumps.
There are pre-sealed and pre-swollen areas.
Red threads encircle the eyes, with hair standing on end.
Pimples appear like dirt, with foul breath that repels others.
The hair begins to clench the teeth.
The hair starts to twist the tongue.
Both cheeks are flushed red, without a single pimple.
Emerging like needles.
Darkness sinks awkwardly.
Purple spots float like duckweed.
There are flea-like marks.
Clusters of unusual pimples resembling beads.
Awful colors and the corresponding treatment.
Four types of poison emerge.
The pimples are good evidence of malice.
White pimples are bold indicators.
Impending flow.
Bubbles surge.[422p]

Ode to the Whirlwind - Song, Shao Yong [469p]

　　　　 臂痛吟　宋·邵雍
　　　　 有病吟　宋·邵雍
　　　　 又　宋·邵雍
　　　　 伤杜婴　宋·王安石
　　　　 其二　宋·王安石
　　　　 赠医者邓献匡　宋·杨时
　　　　 和朱松坡　宋·文天祥
　　　　 赠蜀医锺正甫　宋·文天祥　　　　 彭通伯卫和堂　宋·文天祥　　　　 赠撄宁生　明·宋禧
　　　　 赠杨医官　明·陈琛
　　　　 赠殷矩　明·赵鹤
　　　　 题萱寿太医邢生母　明·王世贞　　　　 将赴青州道别医友王昌年　明·王世贞　　　　 即事呈邢邵二医　明·王世贞　　　　 其二　明·王世贞
　　　　 济川篇为太医邢先生题　明·王世贞　　　　 赠义兴宣疡医　明·张羽
